newsitem.title: INDIA: India panel awards ANZ bank $240 mln - papers.
newsitem.headline: India panel awards ANZ bank $240 mln - papers.

text.p: An Indian arbitration panel has ordered a wholly-owned subsidiary of the country's central bank, to pay ANZ Grindlays Bank 8,600 million rupees ($240 million), Indian financial newspapers reported on Sunday.

The award is linked to transactions involving Harshad Mehta, the broker at the centre of a share scandal that rocked Indian stock markets in 1992, the Economic Times and Financial Express dailies reported.

"In a landmark arbitration case ANZ Grindlays Bank today (Saturday) won a massive 8,600 million rupees award (including interest) against National Housing Bank in a securities scam related case involving the crediting of cheques to Harshad Mehta's account," the Financial Express said.

The Reserve Bank of India (RBI), the central bank, had ordered Grindlays, part of Sydney-based Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, to repay National Housing Bank 5,065.4 million rupees in its efforts to unravel Mehta's financial dealings once the share scandal erupted.
The three member arbitration panel, in a split decision, has ordered the National Housing Bank to hand the money back to Grindlays, together with around 4,000 million rupees interest.
The National Housing Bank, backed by the RBI, is likely to challenge the panel's decision, first through a Special Court of Justice and later through the Supreme Court, the Financial Express said.
